newsitem.title: USA: U.S. lumber industry tries to plug quota loophole.
newsitem.headline: U.S. lumber industry tries to plug quota loophole.

text.p: The U.S. lumber industry is trying to close what it sees as a loophole in a lumber pact that allows framing studs with a hole drilled through one end to enter the United States from Canada, industry sources said.
The holes are enough to classify the studs as modified or manufactured lumber, which exempts them from being counted as part of Canada's quota-regulated lumber exports to the U.S., thr sources said.
"It's not a big deal right now," said Scott Shotwell, executive director of the Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports.
"It could become a big loophole because there is about four billion board feet (of normal studs) coming in a year," Shotwell said.

Under an agreement with the United States, Canada can ship 14.7 billion board feet of lumber annually to the U.S. duty-free. Quantities beyond that amount are subject to a tariff of $50 per 1,000 board feet. If the excess exceeds 650 million board feet, the tariff goes to $100.
"It is being done wholly to bypass the agreement," said John Ragosta, a Coalition lawyer, referring to the drilled studs.
The Coalition, which represents about 65 percent of U.S. softwood lumber manufacturers, is trying to persuade the U.S. Customs Service to disallow the practice.
"We are talking with Customs and saying a stud is a stud," Shotwell said.
Customs officials were unavailable for comment Thursday.
Studs are 2x4s about eight feet in length, used in walls of homes.
Canfor Corp, a Vancouver, British Columbia-based forestry company, began producing modified studs for the Canadian market in 1996 and is now shipping them to the U.S.
"It doesn't qualify under the quota, but we do pay a duty," said Ralph Eastman, Canfor's manager of corporate communications.
U.S. lumber sources said the U.S. assesses duties on imports of quota-exempt lumber, but that the duties are much lower than the tariffs would be if the quota was exceeded.
"We introduced it (the modified lumber) in Canada first and now we are trying to market it in the U.S.," Eastman said.
He said the modified studs account for about three to four percent of the firm's total production, and "what is exported to the U.S. is even smaller."
The studs are designed for housing and the holes were added to accommodate electrical wiring, he said.
Dave Evans, associate editor of the lumber trade publication Random Lengths, said the mill had apparently found a loophole in the Canadian-U.S. lumber agreement.
"If a significant volume of studs were drilled, that would give them (mills) room to ship other (lumber) dimensions. That would basically negate the effectiveness of the agreement," Evans said.
